articles.author: Midi Libre
articles.title: Violent storms: large hailstones, destroyed fields, torn roofs ... images of the bad weather that occurred this - Midi Libre
articles.description: Severe weather events hit the South-West of France on Tuesday, June 20th, causing hailstorms and damage. The storms caused significant damage in the Pyrénées-Atlantiques, Landes, Gers, and Tarn-et-Garonne, with fallen trees and roofs being ripped off. The Basque Country was hit by hailstorms, causing considerable damage to crops. In the North, there were also reports of flooding. While no department is currently on orange alert for storms, yellow vigilance has been issued for several French territories, and storms could spoil the Fête de la Musique.

articles.author: WELT
articles.title: Study on men and violence: Why the "study" was not an isolated case - WELT
articles.description: This article discusses how scientific studies have become the gold standard for objective truth in the media, but the trend of presenting statements from current scientific publications as indisputable truths in journalism is still prevalent. The article cites an example of a recent news story that claimed every third young man in Germany supports violence against women, which was initially reported as a "study" but later changed to an "survey." The article raises concerns about the accuracy and reliability of scientific studies and their reporting in the media.

articles.author: HT Tech
articles.title: Biggest ever space explosion! Astronomers shocked, have no idea where it came from - HT Tech
articles.description: Astronomers believe the space event is the largest explosion ever observed.
articles.content: According to researchers at the University of Southampton, a massive space explosion was discovered that was ten times brighter than any known supernova (exploding star) and three times brighter than… [+1495 chars]

articles.author: DER STANDARD
articles.title: Central Matura this year a little better at AHS, worse at BHS - DER STANDARD
articles.description: This article discusses the results of the central high school exams in Austria, with a focus on the differences in math scores between academic and vocational schools. Despite some lower scores in math, there were very few failing grades overall. The article also mentions the start of the exams in Latin and Greek.

articles.author: RND
articles.title: Submersible "Titan": Rescue workers probably hear knocking noises in the Atlantic - RND
articles.description: The "Titan" submarine with five people on board has been missing since Sunday in the North Atlantic while on its way to the famous wreck of the "Titanic". Rescue teams are searching for it and have reportedly heard regular knocking sounds, giving hope that there may still be survivors. However, a white, rectangular object was also discovered in the water, and further investigation is needed. The US Navy is sending a deep-sea recovery system to help with the search.

articles.author: HT Tech
articles.title: Terrifying solar flare sparks BLACKOUTS in US, Canada; NASA satellite spots blast - HT Tech
articles.description: A powerful solar flare explosion occurred on the Sun, causing shortwave radio blackouts over North America. A coronal mass ejection (CME) cloud was also seen escaping, which has researchers worried. The CME has been classified as Type II solar radio emission and could bring G5-class geomagnetic storms to Earth, which can disrupt GPS, wireless communications, radio waves, and damage power grids and sensitive electronics. The Earth may not be in the strike zone, but nothing can be said for certain until NOAA prediction models arrive.

articles.author: Business Insider Deutschland
articles.title: Our entire universe could be evaporating, researchers believe - Business Insider Canada
articles.description: Scientists at a Dutch university have discovered that massive objects emit Hawking radiation, confirming Stephen Hawking's theory that black holes evaporate by emitting this radiation. The researchers found that an event horizon is not necessary for the radiation to occur, meaning that even objects without an event horizon, such as the remnants of dead stars, could emit this type of radiation. The findings could have implications for the future of the universe, as the radiation and evaporation could cause everything in the universe to eventually evaporate. The study can be found in the scientific journal "Physical Review Letters."

articles.author: futurezone.de
articles.title: World's oldest water discovered: Researchers are fascinated - then try it - futurezone.de
articles.description: Geologists discovered flowing water in a Canadian mine that is at least two billion years old and has chemical traces of ancient microbes. The water was found at a depth of about three kilometers and is considered the oldest water ever found on Earth. The discovery could provide clues to where life may exist elsewhere in the solar system, such as in the oceans on the ice moons of Saturn and Jupiter. The water has a salty and bitter taste and is much saltier than seawater.

articles.author: Mirage News
articles.title: Scientists Confirm Modern Horses Lost Additional Toes - Mirage News
articles.description: The ancestors of modern horses had hooved toes instead of a single hoof, according to a study by an international team of scientists. The study analysed hoof prints and foot bones from modern horses and fossil records to discover what happened to the lost digits. The researchers confirmed that the toes have been completely lost in evolution, not somehow retained within the hoof, as proposed in another recent paper published in the same journal in 2018.

articles.author: ORF Vorarlberg
articles.title: An above-average warm summer is imminent - ORF Vorarlberg
articles.description: Long-term weather models suggest that this year's summer in Europe will be warmer than average, according to Alexander Radlherr from Geosphere Austria. Cool summers are becoming increasingly unlikely due to climate change. The warm weather has already started, with temperatures in Vorarlberg expected to exceed 30 degrees Celsius. Radlherr predicts that this is just the beginning, and that Europe could experience record-breaking heatwaves this summer due to the warm North Atlantic and Mediterranean.

articles.author: ORF.at
articles.title: Study: Groundwater extraction shifts the North Pole - news - ORF.at
articles.description: A new study from South Korea shows that the extraction of groundwater due to the climate crisis is shifting the Earth's axis, causing the geographic North Pole to move in an unexpected direction at a speed of 4.36 centimeters per year. The global net loss of groundwater from natural underground reservoirs between 1993 and 2010 is estimated to be more than two trillion tons, according to the study. The depletion of groundwater has been caused largely by irrigation, particularly in northwest India and western North America, and has contributed to a global sea level rise of 6.24 millimeters between 1993 and 2010.

articles.author: Newswise
articles.title: Climate change could lead to "widespread chaos" for insect communities - Newswise
articles.description: This article discusses a study conducted by Thomas H.Q. Powell, an assistant professor of biological sciences at Binghamton University, State University of New York, on the impact of climate change on the evolution of the apple maggot fly. The study found that the apple maggot fly, a major agricultural pest, began to diverge into two populations in the Hudson Valley in the 1850s, with one population shifting to a new food source: apple trees. The study found that the two fly populations responded to temperature shifts in starkly different ways, with the hawthorn-dwellers appearing to have more resilience. The study has important ramifications for insect biodiversity.

articles.author: TN.cz
articles.title: The astronomical summer is starting. It will bring tropical temperatures and strong thunderstorms | TN.cz - TN.cz
articles.description: This article discusses the start of summer and the expected weather conditions in the Czech Republic. The beginning of summer will bring tropical temperatures and strong storms. The article also mentions the possibility of tropical nights and the potential for temperature records to be broken. The weather is expected to calm down over the weekend, with temperatures around 20-26°C. The article also provides a seasonal weather forecast for the summer.
